docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As a self-employed, self-insured person, I own one of those expensive high-deductible insurance policies that Allan B. Hubbard seems to think will make Americans healthier. This is how it works for me.

headline.main: Squeezed in the Health Care Maze

docs.abstract: Amy S Khoudari letter says Allan Hubbard's assertion that high-deductible insurance policies will make Americans healthier is flawed; shares her experience with such insurance (April 3 Op-Ed article)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     As a self-employed, self-insured person, I own one of those expensive high-deductible insurance policies that Allan B. Hubbard seems to think will make Americans healthier.     This is how it works for me.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: To hear Allan B. Hubbard tell it, I would be better off with a Health Savings Account and a high-deductible insurance policy so that I could go out into the marketplace with other consumers to drive down the price of health care. The problem with this rosy picture is that as just about anyone with health insurance knows, the insurance companies often pay 50 percent or less of the ''list price'' for medical services. This is because the large insurance companies have bargaining power with health care providers.

headline.main: Squeezed in the Health Care Maze

docs.abstract: James G Roberts letter says consumers on their own cannot negotiate prices that insurance companies can; says Allan Hubbard's rosy picture of Health Savings Accounts is not based on reality (April 3 Op-Ed article)

docs.lead_paragraph: INSTANT messaging has come of age. No longer the province of chatty teenagers, it is now part and parcel of advanced communications networks at many corporations. And as instant messaging takes hold, companies are benefiting from new productivity gains and improvements in customer response time. ''I almost never get e-mail from my Sun colleagues,'' said Tim Bray, an avid instant messager and director of Web technologies for Sun Microsystems. ''And I only get voice mails from outsiders.''

headline.main: I.M. Generation Is Changing the Way Business Talks

docs.abstract: Instant messaging is no longer province of teenagers, but has become part of advanced communications networks at many corporations; sign of growing corporate rise of IM usage came earlier in year when IBM opened its messaging platform to other messaging systems; it has become latest trend in information technology, changing how corporate world converses and allowing it to respond rapidly to demands from inside and outside; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Striking workers at Sikorsky Aircraft Company voted by a narrow margin to approve a contract with the company, Sikorsky announced yesterday. The vote, which The Associated Press reported as 1,488 in favor and 1,416 opposed, ended a six-week strike. The workers will receive a pay raise of roughly 11 percent over three years, a company spokesman said, but will have to make increased contributions for health insurance. The workers will begin to return over the next seven days, and the company is scheduled to return to full production by next Monday, said Bud Grebey, a company spokesman. A phone call to a union representative was not returned yesterday evening. Sikorsky is a leading manufacturer of helicopters.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Stratford: Sikorsky Contract Approved

docs.abstract: Sikorsky Aircraft Co, leading manufacturer of helicopters in Connecticut, says striking workers have approved contract by narrow margin and will receive pay raise of roughly 11 percent over three years; workers will make increased contributions to health insurance (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN the past five years, private health insurance premiums have risen 73 percent. Some businesses have responded by dropping healthcare coverage, leaving employees uninsured. Other employers pass the costs on to workers, both by raising co-payments and premiums and by denying workers the wage increases they need to afford these higher prices. What is driving this unsustainable run-up in health insurance costs, and how can we make things better?
docs.snippet: Heath Savings Accounts give consumers more choices for health care, while strengthening their role in reducing waste.

docs.lead_paragraph: HOMEOWNERS are not the only ones struggling to balance their budgets in the face of rising fuel costs and medical insurance coverage. County school districts are girding for their annual rite of passage: preparing and (they hope) passing the school budget, which this year will be presented to voters on May 16. The ritual holds special challenges this year, with administrators caught in a financial straitjacket that leaves little room for program enhancements.
docs.abstract: Westchester County school districts gird for annual school budgets, which will be presented to voters on May 16; accounting changes in New York State's employee retirement plan as well as rising employee health-care costs are expected to take significant share of increased spending proposals; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IT is asserted both as fact and as argument: the United States needs a constant flow of immigrants to perform jobs Americans will not stoop to do. But what if those jobs paid $50 an hour, with benefits, instead of $7 or $10 or $15?

headline.main: Immigrants and the Economics of Hard Work

docs.abstract: Most comprehensive recent study of immigrant workers comes from Center for Immigration Studies, group that advocates stricter controls on immigration; study, by center's research director, Steven A Camarota, found that immigrants are majority of workers in only 4 of 473 job classifications--stucco masons, tailors, produce sorters and beauty salon workers; Camarota disputes contention that there are jobs that Americans will not do; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Does the United States need a constant flow of immigrants to perform jobs Americans will not stoop to do?
